Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Personalizing Recommendations in a Large-scale Education Analytics Pipeline

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This pilot project aims to begin to organize the world's digital learning resources to make personalized recommendations to learners that are engaging and effective in increasing mathematics learning outcomes. The project accomplishes this goal by developing crowdsourcing techniques to organize learning resources and by analyzing the online learning activities of the student. Teachers are an integral part of this project. The target audience for this pilot is 7th grade mathematics students and teachers.

This project builds upon the Gooru platform that serves a community of over 500,000 in 140 countries and all 50 US states. The platform uses crowdsourcing by its community to curate over 70,000 collections of free web resources consisting of over 16,000,000 education resources. This project builds upon the Gooru resources by using learning analytics on the user interactions within Gooru to discover the resources that most benefit students. Thus, student resources can be tailored to the individual student to maximally engage the student and improve the student's learning. Since the Gooru user owns his or her data, explicit opt-in is required for the sharing of data thus protecting the privacy of students who wish not to share their data. Gooru is open source and free so there are no economic barriers (besides internet access) to using the platform.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Gooru took a novel technical approach by developing a route planner in a massively large and dynamic environment as “web-search” with keywords inferred based on learners’ preferences, contexts, and proficiencies. They formalized their approach as a “social machine for mediated learning environments” which is summarized here: The web is seen as a promising platform for scaling formal educational practices across large populations. However, much of the efforts in this space use the web primarily as an amplifier over existing models of learning that is based on the classroom. Instead, we argue for modeling large-scale online learning environments as “social machines”, rather than as large classrooms. We propose a pedagogy model called “mediated learning” where the web acts as a platform to nurture a learning community, by continuously mediating between knowledge need and expertise. Mediated learning has the potential to “invert the learning pyramid” by interfacing the learner with several experts as part of a single learning experience. Supporting mediated learning needs an approach that is data-intensive, as well as be driven by social semantics. A social machine architecture was proposed for mediated-learning environments that is characterized by four layers of operation, namely: Data, Analytics, Semantics and Mediation.

Field work was carried out with Leadership Public Schools (LPS), a charter school management organization that operates high schools in the San Francisco Bay Area. With partners at LPS, Gooru developed a set of math courses within a feature called the Navigator. These course resources were used in LPS’s Academic Numeracy classes. The design of the Navigator was built around three core principles: give students real-time feedback on learning progress, give students the ability to choose learning activities within the framework and select learning resources, and give students opportunity to develop non-cognitive learning-related skills (e.g., goal settings, time management, etc.). 

Toward the development of an education analytics platform, Gooru designed a data management and analytics platform to collect, organize, and share anonymized learning activities streams. Data are accumulated in a scalable “data lake” implemented on a cloud-hosted, high-performance, massively-scalable NoSQL database management system. Data are then selectively mined from the data lake, proceed through transformation and cleansing routines, and managed in a data management service that was intended to support exploratory analysis by researchers as well as programmatic interfaces using modern web services protocols. Researchers affiliated with Gooru utilized the analytics platform from early exploration to algorithm design and testing. 

While the developments internal to Gooru, in consultation with the UCB PI and students, were many, the realization of a data pipeline that could expose necessary data to external colalborators was not fully achieved. Algorithms were developed at UCB for estimating cognitive mastery based on sample learning process data from Gooru with a prototype taxonomy of learning objectives contributed by a combination of Gooru users and instructional designers. These prototypes were exhibited at AERA (Gogel, Pardos, 2015). The algorithms ultimately were not able to be seamlessly connected to the platform by way of a real-time data API. Instead, considerable manual orechestration of limited data exports was required. A constantly changing platform pedagogical design and subsequently changing learning objective taxonomy served as challenges to consistent data collection and data schema design needed for a reliable data API specification. Lesson learned from this EAGER collaboration informed design decisions of subsequent work impleneting data collection processes and a personalized navigational recommender in a massive open online learning environment (Pardos, Tang, Davis, Le, 2017).
